isis.stitle: DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service (1990) - CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS, RINGS AND SLEEVES - CYLINDER SLEEVE REMOVAL - CONNECTING RODS

svcproc.title: CONNECTING RODS

step1.para: Visually inspect the connecting rod bolts for nicks or damage.

note.para: WHEN LUBRICATED WITH CLEAN ENGINE OIL, THE BOLTS MUST SCREW INTO THE ROD BY HAND. IF RESISTANCE IS MET, RECLEAN THE ROD THREADS AND TRY A NEW BOLT. IF A NEW BOLT DOES NOT SCREW IN FREELY, THE ROD MUST BE DISCARDED.

step1.para: Visually inspect the rod and cap mating surfaces for fretting. Replace as required.
Inspect the connecting rod piston pin bushing for wear as follows:

step2.para:
Using a telescoping gauge and an outside micrometer, measure pin bore at two locations and record the readings ( Figure 6.24
).
Refer to "SPECIFICATIONS". If the piston pin bushing I.D. exceeds the minimum specification, it is worn and must be replaced.

step1.para: Remove any worn bushing using a press and a driver.

Clean the connecting rod piston pin bushing bore thoroughly and visually inspect for defects. Using a telescoping gauge and a micrometer, measure the connecting rod piston pin bushing bore diameter at two locations. Refer to Figure 6.25
. If out of "SPECIFICATIONS", replace the connecting rod.

figure.caption: Figure 6.24. Check Piston Pin Bushing I.D.
Figure 6.25. Check Connecting Rod Piston Pin Bushing Bore Diameter.

step1.para: Check the connecting rod bearing bore for "out-of-round" as follows:

step2.para: Lubricate connecting rod bolts with clean engine oil and assemble the cap to the rod without the bearing insert. Tighten the bolts to the specified torque.

Use an inside micrometer or a dial bore gauge and measure the connecting rod in three locations as shown in Figure 6.26
.
If the difference between point "B" and the average of points "A" and "C" ([A + C] ÷ 2), exceeds the "SPECIFICATIONS", the rod must be replaced.

step1.para:
Measure the connecting rod bearing bore taper ( Figure 6.27
), by measuring the bore I.D. on each side of the bearing bore. Record the readings. The difference between the two readings is the bore taper (See "SPECIFICATIONS"). Replace rod as required.
With the connecting rod cap removed, visually inspect the surface finish of the connecting rod bearing bore. The bore must be smooth and free of scoring, nicks or burrs. Replace as required.

step2.para: A shiny surface on edge of piston pin bushing usually indicates that a connecting rod is bent or piston pin hole is not in proper relation to piston skirt and ring grooves.
Abnormal connecting rod bearing wear can be caused by either a bent connecting rod or a tapered connecting rod bore.

Twisted connecting rods will not create an easily identifiable wear pattern, but badly twisted rods will disturb action of entire piston, rings, and connecting rod assembly and may be the cause of excessive oil consumption.

note.para: IF THE CONNECTING RODS DO NOT MEET THE REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN PARAGRAPHS 1-9 "CONNECTING ROD INSPECTION", REPLACE THE ENTIRE CONNECTING ROD ASSEMBLY.
